item.title: Shell execution commands â€” source bash and dot
item.description:
The note is generated by “ChatGPT”.

ğŸ”¹ source

  • Executes a script in the current shell environment.
  • Does not create a new shell process.
  • All variable exports, alias definitions, and PATH modifications remain active after execution.
  • Commonly used for reloading configuration files (e.g., source ~/.bashrc).
  • Bash and Zsh built-in command.

Example:

1

source ~/.bashrc

â†’ Reloads your Bash configuration immediately in the current session.

ğŸ”¹ bash

  • Starts a new Bash subshell to run the script.
  • The parent shell does not inherit any environment changes.
  • Safer for running scripts that should not affect your current session.
  • Suitable for installation, automation, or isolated execution.

Example:

item.title: Git é…ç½®PAT
item.description:
The note is partly generated by “ChatGPT.”

The article â€œProxy set, but ssh -T git@github.com still failsâ€ explains that Git SSH cannot use an HTTP proxy and provides a solution. However, in my experience, even using that solution, network performance can be unreliable. Therefore, if you can use HTTPS for Git, I recommend switching from SSH to HTTPS directly. Below is the method to switch to HTTPS and configure a Personal Access Token (PAT) for authentication.

item.title: Proxy set, but ssh -T git@github.com still fails
item.description:
The note is generated by ChatGPT.

Observation â€” Proxy set, but SSH still fails

Although you set http_proxy / https_proxy (or all_proxy), running:

1

ssh -T git@github.com

still times out or fails.

Root cause â€” SSH does NOT use the HTTP proxy (key point)

Terminal HTTP/SOCKS environment variables affect HTTP/HTTPS-aware programs (curl, wget, git clone https://â€¦, etc.), but OpenSSH does not honor those variables. SSH opens a raw TCP connection and must be explicitly told to use a proxy â€” otherwise it tries a direct connection and gets blocked by the network/firewall.

item.title: 10 Terminal Tricks
item.description:
Hereâ€™s a cheat sheet of â€œ10 Terminal Tricks Most Developers Donâ€™t Know (But Should)â€ by Rishabh Agarwal: Level Up Coding

ğŸ” Command History & Navigation

Shortcut / Command Description
Ctrl + R Reverse-search previously used commands from history.
!! Re-run the last executed command.
cd - Switch back to the previous directory.

ğŸ§­ Cursor Movement

Shortcut Description
Ctrl + A Jump to the start of the current command line.
Ctrl + E Jump to the end of the current command line.
Alt + â† / â†’ Move the cursor word-by-word (instead of character-by-character).

âœ‚ï¸ Editing Commands

Shortcut Description
Ctrl + U Delete from cursor to the start of the line.
Ctrl + K Delete from cursor to the end of the line.

âš¡ Autocomplete & Suggestions

Shortcut Description
<Tab> <Tab> Show all possible command or path completions.

ğŸ§¹ Utility

Shortcut Description
Ctrl + L Clear the terminal screen instantly.

item.title: Trash-cli â€” The Recycle Bin on Linux
item.description:
ğŸ“˜ Overview

On Linux, the command-line tool trash-cli provides a safe alternative to rm, allowing you to move files to the Trash instead of permanently deleting them.
It fully complies with the FreeDesktop Trash Specification, which is used by desktop environments such as GNOME and KDE.

ğŸ§° Installation

You can install trash-cli using your package manager or Pythonâ€™s pip:

1
2
3

sudo apt install trash-cli
# or
pip install trash-cli

ğŸš« Disable rm (for safety)

To avoid accidental permanent deletions, you can override the rm command and display a friendly warning instead.

item.title: Use tmux save-buffer to sync clipboard
item.description:
The note is generated by ChatGPT.

This note explains how to:

  1. Synchronize text copied in a remote Neovim session with your local clipboard via tmux.
  2. Implement a cpwd command to copy the current working directory of your shell to the local clipboard.
  3. Understand the underlying principle of how tmux buffers bridge remote Neovim and local clipboard.

1. Prerequisites

  • tmux 3.3a+ (supports load-buffer -w)
  • Neovim installed on the remote server

2. Principle: How tmux Buffers Bridge Remote and Local Clipboard

  1. tmux Buffers as an Intermediate Clipboard

ğŸ‘‰ Please use trash-cli instead. It is safer and provides these commands:

 trash-put / trash â†’ Move files/directories to trash
 trash-empty â†’ Empty the trashcan(s)
 trash-list â†’ List trashed files
 trash-restore â†’ Restore a trashed file
 trash-rm â†’ Remove individual files from trash

ğŸ“‹ æ¦‚è¿°

æœ¬æŒ‡å—ä»‹ç»å¦‚ä½•åœ¨ WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux) ä¸­é…ç½®å’Œä½¿ç”¨ Windows ä¸»æœºä¸Šçš„ SOCKS5 ä»£ç†ï¼Œå®ç°ç½‘ç»œè®¿é—®çš„ä»£ç†åŠŸèƒ½ã€‚

ğŸ› ï¸ é…ç½®æ­¥éª¤

1. åˆ›å»ºä»£ç†é…ç½®æ–‡ä»¶

åˆ›å»ºæ–‡ä»¶ ~/.bash_proxy å¹¶æ·»åŠ ä»¥ä¸‹å†…å®¹ï¼š

# ==================== ä»£ç†ç®¡ç†å‡½æ•° ====================

# è·å– Windows ä¸»æœº IP
get_hostip() {
 cat /etc/resolv.conf | grep nameserver | awk '{print $2}'
}

# å¼€å¯ä»£ç†
proxy_on() {
 export hostip=$(get_hostip)
 export ALL_PROXY="socks5://${hostip}:10810"
 export HTTP_PROXY="socks5://${hostip}:10810"
 export HTTPS_PROXY="socks5://${hostip}:10810"
 export http_proxy="socks5://${hostip}:10810"
 export https_proxy="socks5://${hostip}:10810"
 
 echo "ğŸ”“ ä»£ç†å·²å¼€å¯"
 echo " SOCKS5: socks5://${hostip}:10810"
}

# å…³é—­ä»£ç†
proxy_off() {
 unset ALL_PROXY
 unset HTTP_PROXY
 unset HTTPS_PROXY
 unset http_proxy
 unset https_proxy
 unset hostip
 
 echo "ğŸ”’ ä»£ç†å·²å…³é—­"
}

# æ˜¾ç¤ºä»£ç†çŠ¶æ€
proxy_status() {
 if [ -n "$ALL_PROXY" ]; then
 echo "ğŸŸ¢ ä»£ç†çŠ¶æ€: å¼€å¯"
 echo " ALL_PROXY=$ALL_PROXY"
 echo " HTTP_PROXY=$HTTP_PROXY"
 echo " HTTPS_PROXY=$HTTPS_PROXY"
 else
 echo "ğŸ”´ ä»£ç†çŠ¶æ€: å…³é—­"
 fi
}

# æµ‹è¯•ä»£ç†è¿æ¥
proxy_test() {
 echo "ğŸ§ª æµ‹è¯•ä»£ç†è¿æ¥..."
 if curl -s --connect-timeout 10 -I https://www.google.com > /dev/null; then
 echo "âœ… ä»£ç†è¿æ¥æˆåŠŸ"
 else
 echo "âŒ ä»£ç†è¿æ¥å¤±è´¥"
 fi
}

# å¿«é€Ÿåˆ‡æ¢ä»£ç†
proxy_switch() {
 if [ -n "$ALL_PROXY" ]; then
 proxy_off
 else
 proxy_on
 fi
}

# æ˜¾ç¤ºå½“å‰ç½‘ç»œä¿¡æ¯
proxy_info() {
 echo "ğŸŒ ç½‘ç»œä¿¡æ¯:"
 echo " WSL IP: $(hostname -I 2>/dev/null | awk '{print $1}')"
 echo " Windows IP: $(get_hostip)"
 echo " ä»£ç†ç«¯å£: 10810"
}

2. ä¿®æ”¹ Bash é…ç½®æ–‡ä»¶

item.title: æ¨å¯¼ä¸¤ä¸ªä¸€ç»´æ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒçš„KLæ•£åº¦
item.description:
è®¾

$$
P(x) \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu_1, \sigma_1^2), \quad Q(x) \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu_2, \sigma_2^2)
$$

å®šä¹‰

$$
D_{\mathrm{KL}}(P\lVert Q) = \int P(x) \log \frac{P(x)}{Q(x)} dx
$$

åˆ™æœ‰

$$
\boxed{
D_{\mathrm{KL}}(P\lVert Q) = \ln \frac{\sigma_2}{\sigma_1} + \frac{(\sigma_1^2 - \sigma_2^2) + (\mu_1 - \mu_2)^2}{2\sigma_2^2}
}
$$

Step 1. åˆ†å¸ƒæ¯”å€¼

$$
\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)} = \frac{\sigma_2}{\sigma_1} \exp \left[ \frac{\sigma_1^2(x - \mu_2)^2 - \sigma_2^2(x - \mu_1)^2}{2\sigma_1^2\sigma_2^2} \right]
$$

å› æ­¤

$$
\log \frac{P(x)}{Q(x)} = \ln \frac{\sigma_2}{\sigma_1} + \frac{(\sigma_1^2 - \sigma_2^2)x^2 + (2\sigma_2^2\mu_1 - 2\sigma_1^2\mu_2)x + (\sigma_1^2\mu_2^2 - \mu_1^2\sigma_2^2)}{2\sigma_1^2\sigma_2^2}
$$

Regardless of whether I ask a question in English or Chinese, you must answer in English. If I ask a question in English, you must first point out any grammatical errors and offer more appropriate wording before answering. If I ask a question in Chinese, you must first translate my question into English before answering in English.

Presentations using Slides

A demo on how to build presentations using Slides.

Formatting

You can use regular Markdown formatting, like emphasised and bold text.
